p: After detailed data cleaning and spatial balancing, our initial total of 5107 occurrence points for I. ricinus from diverse sources was filtered and reduced to 416 spatially unique points at 10â€™ resolution. This data filtering reduced problems associated with artificial clumping of occurrence records, which is related to biases in sampling and reporting ( Fig 1). Calibrating models for I. ricinus based on the 5 subgroups of occurrence points yielded predictions that gave area under the curve (AUC) ratios above null expectations in all five partial ROC analyses ( P < 0.001; S2 File). The I. ricinus model successfully anticipated 3110 records out of the additional 3186 test records, which was significantly better than random expectations (P < 0.001; S3 File). Annual precipitation, annual temperature range, and annual mean temperature were the most influential factors and contributed >86% to the Maxent model ( S4 File).
